awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Robust Signal Recovery and Grant-Free Access for Massive IoT Connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in information technologies, computers, and microelectronics have led to transformative innovations and broad deployment of smart devices with data computation and communication capabilities. Internet of things (IoT) products and services are playing increasingly important roles in many fields such as smart city, e-health, agriculture, safety, security, and environmental protection. In particular, low-power massive IoT applications already account for over 60% of the IoT market which continues to expand at a relentless pace. Low-power wireless IoT devices are primarily deployed for sensing and data collection with uplink dominated traffic. Given the massive number of such devices, traditional channel access based on coordinated scheduling between base-station and the multitude of end-user devices consumes too much bandwidth and device energy. Uncoordinated uplink access can overcome both obstacles but at the risk of multi-device signal collisions. This research project develops novel technologies for reliable and efficient reception of simultaneous multi-device wireless transmissions in networks that support massive number of low power IoT terminals. This work contributes to vital technological advancement that can significantly impact the current and future applications of wireless IoT services. The research outcomes shall contribute substantially to the theoretical foundation of signal processing and optimization, as well as to the design of network protocols to support massive connectivity in practical 5G and Beyond wireless systems.

Specifically, the project activities focus on the design, analysis, and optimization of advanced wireless network receivers to effectively decode and recover data packets that are often in collision when multiple devices spontaneously transmit over their shared wireless channel spectrum. Effective recovery of data packets under collision improves both spectral efficiency and energy efficiency for a large population of low power devices. Specifically, the researchers shall investigate novel solutions for simultaneous signal recovery from multiple device transmissions in both local area and wide area network environments. Subject to unknown channel distortions and mutual interference, wireless receivers must recover co-channel user packets from simultaneous uplink transmissions via blind demixing. The research team will tackle the challenging and difficult problem of blind demixing by advancing the theory, algorithm, and hardware for low-rank and sparse matrix completion. The researchers shall develop novel algorithms that are faster and more effective with desired global convergence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Internet of Things (IoT) services are playing increasingly important roles in many critical applications such as smart city, infrastructure, automation, safety, defense, and environmental protection. Wireless communications and networking in future IoT networks critically depend on technological advances in massive IoT connectivity, low complexity medium access, and high spectral efficiency. Low-power massive IoT applications already account for over 60 percent of the IoT market and are continuing to grow. Recently standardized solutions such as narrowband (NB) IoT for 5G networks as well as proprietary technologies such as SigFox and Lora have begun to address some vital issues associated with low power-IoT and massive connectivity including battery life, rate, cost, coverage, and channel access. One critical design challenge lies in the tradeoff between long battery life and high spectral efficiency required for supporting massive connectivity with limited bandwidth. The former requires simple and efficient access protocols whereas the latter demands controlled access for high spectrum efficiency. Traditional cellular networks rely on dedicated control channels for the massive number of IoT devices, which would consume substantial bandwidth for transmitting control signals and power for LP-IoT devices to monitor and acquire designated control signals. Grant-free and over-the-air multiuser network access can overcome both obstacles.  This project centers on the design and optimization of multi-user data transceivers that can significantly improve spectrum efficiency, shorten latency, lower software/hardware complexity, enhance networking flexibility, resist interference or jamming, and extend terminal battery life.

One major outcome of this project is the development of new and robust solutions to recover mixtures of multiple signals transmitted simultaneously. We designed Wirtinger flow and Riemann orthogonal constant modulus algorithms that achieved full recovery of multiple access signals without large data sample size or special initialization. Our investigation of grant-free access also led to the development of another novel over-the-air learning framework for collaborative decision making in wireless sensor networks. This new low complexity framework leverages low-latency sensor transmission for a decision server to coordinate measurement sensors for  hypothesis testing through over-the-air aggregation of sensor data over a shared wireless channel. Over-the-air computation allows all information to be simultaneously transmitted without controlling channel access since soft decision signals from all participant nodes are aggregated naturally at the receiver of the central decision maker. In a hybrid protocol that involves both access grant and grant-free access, transceivers with multiple antennas allow multiple users to share a common channel in multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) wireless links. Such a hybrid protocol involves both access grant and grant-free access. To serve a large number of users in such a scenario,  we propose an effective and scalable user scheduling paradigm by dividing grant-free users into groups. Our system aims to group users with low mutual interference into groups to effectively and efficiently utilize power and spectrum.  This design approach is generalizable to a variety of different simple and scalable unsupervised learning tools and different diversity optimization criteria. This project also studied a variety of other machine learning tools for wireless communications and developed several innovative solutions with substantial performance gains.  These findings have been reported in peer-reviewed journals and conferences.  In workforce development, multiple graduate student researchers and/or post-doctoral researchers have been trained and supported by this project. All PhDS graduates supported by this grant have either joined the tech companies or continued to work in academia.
